newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish PM says religious education rights issue.
newsitem.headline: Turkish PM says religious education rights issue.

text.p: Turkey's Islamist Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan said on Thursday that denying pupils the right to attend Moslem religious schools amounted to a human rights abuse, the state-run Anatolian news agency reported.

"Respect for human rights is the issue we will highlight most when resolving the problem of education in our country," said Erbakan, the first Islamist to lead 99 percent Moslem Turkey since it became a secular republic in 1923.
"It is the most natural right of people to teach their religion to their children from a young age...This is a right recognised in the United Nations and European human rights declarations," he said.
Erbakan was speaking in opposition to a plan demanded by the powerful army that compulsory education be increased to eight years in the same school from the current five.
This would effectively shut down the middle section of state religious schools, which now begin to take pupils at 11.
Turkey's secularists, particularly the military, believe that the religious "imam hatip" schools are used as a breeding ground for activists in Erbakan's Welfare Party.
Erbakan came to power last year after narrowly coming first in general elections with only 21 percent of the vote.
But his coalition with a conservative party has shown cracks under fierce pressure from the secularist generals after he proposed mild Islamist reforms earlier this year.
The eight-year education plan was among demands set out by the military-government National Security Council (MGK) in February.
Erbakan, also a member of the MGK, was a signatory to the council's list of demands, but he has been criticised since for not implementing any of them.
